title: Now reading -topic
content:
Everyone knows those NP (now playing) topics where one posts the name of the current song playing (and its artist). Here's a similar topic dedicated to books you're currently in process of reading. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-dexter.gif[/img]
And after reading one, please tell your comments about the book but NO SPOILERS! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-garg.gif[/img]
Tell the book's name and then its author. I'll start;

A Journey to the Center of the Earth - Jules Verne
The Blunderer - Patricia Highsmith3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: Now reading -topic
content: Wolf Brother and Spirit Walker by Michelle Paver. This is fantasy (aimed at the "kids to teens" level, I think) set back in the Bronze Age, with a bit of magic/spirit stuff mixed in. I get the feeling I should be reading something deep and complicated - but this is fun and easy to pick up, so I like it. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

title: Spleen Reeds.
content:
I've been reading a hell of a lot more in recent months than I pretty much ever have. Previously I was unable to concentrate on reading 20 or more pages at a time, especially when I was bored, but now I've learnt to channel boredom into reading, which is very handy.

Some time ago I finished the Chronicles of Obernewtyn by Isobelle Carmody. 'Twas quite intriguing, but had a rather weird and anticlimatic ending that leaves the story hanging and the characters kinda lost. It looks like Carmody got bored writing the fourth book and wanted to get it over and done with, but also wanted to leave it open for a possible, yet unlikely, fifth book.

More recently I read Geomancer, the first book in Ian Irvine's The Well of Echoes--the first 600-page book I've managed to read in the space of a fortnight. It takes some serious resolve to write something this unrelentingly tragic. So many crushed hopes, broken spirits and disastrous misunderstandings, Irvine afforded his characters absolutely no mercy. Next in line is Tetrarch, which I'll be buying next time I'm in book shop that actually has it in stock.

Currently I'm rereading Myst: The Book of Ti'ana, which I found at a book store in Melbourne when I went up to see H.I.M. I read it back in 2000 or so, followed by the Book of Atrus and later, after playing Myst, the Book of D'Ni. I hadn't played any of the games at this point, so I managed to read/play the entire series up to Myst III (and Uru) in order. I'm yet to play IV and V.

Anybody who hasn't read/played the awesomeness that is the Myst series, must do so ASAP. KeenRush, I'm talking to you. I'm also setting my girlfriend this task once I'm finished reading the first book again. Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

A concerned member of the Preservation of Endangered Spleens Society

[url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/]JimSoft Lair[/url]

Currently reading: Keys to the Kingdom by Garth Nix, Part four, Sir Thursday. I quite like it, and the mysteries are enough to keep you puzzling until the next one comes. I've read it a few times now, but I still can't figure out the deal with 'nothing.'

[hr]

---Freeyorp

title: Tasty literature.
content:
I'm about two thirds of the way through Chimaera, the fourth book in the Well of Echoes quartet I mentioned in my earlier post. The scope is so broad that I can't put many words to it. The world is incredible, the story is intricately designed and the characters evolve through countless hardships which, at the time, appear to be their end (of course, in many cases it is).

There's another quartet before this one that I'm yet to read, and the first book of the next trilogy has recently been released. So there's a lot for me to read yet.

title: Re: Tasty literature.
content:
I've been reading some stuff by Lord Dunsany lately. I read "The Book of Wonder", which was great. Now I'm on "The Gods of Pegana", which is somewhat less so.

I think the last thing I read in dead-tree format was "Anansi Boys", by Neil Gaiman. Then I read "A Study in Emerald" on the computer, also by him, which got me on the Dunsany kick.________________
